properly, heed, i.e. purpose; used only adverbially, on account of (as a motive or an aim), teleologically, in order that
properly, to goad, i.e. (by implication) to teach (the rod being an Oriental incentive)
to fear; morally, to revere; caus. to frighten
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God

gods in the ordinary sense; but specifically used (in the plural thus, especially with the article) of the supreme God; occasionally applied by way of deference to magistrates; and sometimes as a superlative
properly, to hedge about (as with thorns), i.e. guard; generally, to protect, attend to, etc.
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
a word; by implication, a matter (as spoken of) or thing; adverbially, a cause
a precept or statute, especially the Decalogue or Pentateuch
this (often used adverb)
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
an enactment; hence, an appointment (of time, space, quantity, labor or usage)
these or those
to do or make, in the broadest sense and widest application

20.brief: properly, a failure of, i.e. (used only as a negative particle, usually with a prepositional prefix) not, except, without, unless, besides, because not, until, etc.
to be high actively, to rise or raise (in various applications, literally or figuratively)
the heart (as the most interior organ);
a brother (used in the widest sense of literal relationship and metaphorical affinity or resemblance (like father))
properly, a failure of, i.e. (used only as a negative particle, usually with a prepositional prefix) not, except, without, unless, besides, because not, until, etc.
properly, a part of; hence (prepositionally), from or out of in many senses
a command, whether human or divine (collectively, the Law)
the right hand or side (leg, eye) of a person or other object (as the stronger and more dexterous); locally, the south
properly, dark (as enveloped), i.e. the north; hence (by orientation), the left hand
properly, heed, i.e. purpose; used only adverbially, on account of (as a motive or an aim), teleologically, in order that
to be (causative, make) long (literally or figuratively)
a day (as the warm hours), whether literal (from sunrise to sunset, or from one sunset to the next), or figurative (a space of time defined by an associated term), (often used adverb)
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
dominion, i.e. (abstractly) the estate (rule) or (concretely) the country (realm)

he (she or it); only expressed when emphatic or without a verb; also (intensively) self, or (especially with the article) the same; sometimes (as demonstrative) this or that; occasionally (instead of copula) as or are
a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
properly, the nearest part, i.e. the center, whether literal, figurative or adverbial (especially with preposition)
Jisrael, a symbolical name of Jacob; also (typically) of his posterity
